1479148568166367235.text: As we reflect on the horrors of #January6th, it is imperative that we take a moment to read this piece and understand what is unfolding before us. American democracy is under attack, and we all have a responsibility to protect it. https://t.co/UEdYFkTFwb

1479119790199296006.text: As we think about what transpired a year ago, we must all reaffirm our commitment to American democracy and work to ensure it is maintained for generations to come.

1479119740828192769.text: One year later, my colleagues are continuing to investigate those who premeditated and organized this attack. This important work will carry on until we have a comprehensive understanding of what took place and can bring those responsible to justice.

1479119688122523655.text: We mourn the senseless violence that occurred that day and the loss of life while praising the heroic actions of those that defended the U.S. Capitol--the citadel of democracy--from attack.

1479119636448776201.text: Tragically, lives were lost on January 6, 2021, and in the days and months that followed due to the unimaginable trauma experienced by courageous and heroic Capitol Police officers that fought to protect the Capitol.

1479119210554945539.text: Tragically, lives were lost on January 6, 2021, and in the days and months that followed due to the unimaginable trauma experienced by courageous and heroic Capitol Police officers that fought to protect the Capitol.

1479119094641147912.text: That night we returned to the House floor--hours after the attack--to finish our hallowed work and certify the 2020 election. We sent a message to the world that nothing can come in the way of our Constitutional obligations and our dedication to American democracy.

1479119047081934858.text: On that day I said, "Democracy is fragile - it is our responsibility to protect it. Americans have upheld this responsibility through more than two centuries of challenges and adversity. Today, and every day moving forward, we must continue this work."

1479118973761245192.text: One year ago today, a violent mob descended on the U.S. Capitol in an attempt to stage a coup and end American democracy. They threatened members of Congress with violence if we performed our Constitutional duty to certify the lawful result of the 2020 Presidential election.

1470806417875550217.text: The bill saved countless lives, but unfortunately the federal assault weapons ban expired in 2004—leaving our children and our communities more vulnerable as a result.

1470806289324388352.text: In 1989, I introduced in the California Legislature what would become the first assault weapons ban anywhere in America. I introduced the bill in response to a school shooting in my then State Senate district.

1441098516823040002.text: My amendment will strengthen our national security and save billions of tax-payer dollars. I hope my colleagues will join me in this critically important effort to address the modern nuclear arms race and prevent the unnecessary expenditure of billions of taxpayer dollars.

1441098515006967814.text: But more fundamentally, our nuclear posture is centered on a principle of deterrence rather than dominance. Regardless of Chinese nuclear capabilities, our strategic forces are sufficient to deter a nuclear attack on the U.S. or its allies.

1441098513324990470.text: The deployment of GBSD will not impact our deterrence calculus since it will not alter the overall numbers of ground-based ballistic missiles.

1441098511529885712.text:
Opponents will also claim GBSD is needed since China is rapidly expanding its ground-based silo
ICBMs. Even with China’s reported expansion of its nuclear forces, our arsenal still dwarfs China’s.

1441098510024151047.text: Opponents of my amendment will falsely claim that GBSD is more cost-effective. A 2017 CBO report showed that it would cost $37 billion less to life extend the Minutelam III than developing and deploying the GBSD through 2036.

1441098507457228800.text: GBSD would require billions of taxpayer dollars to be spent unnecessarily. It also precipitates a modern nuclear arms race and predicates our nuclear modernization efforts on a strategy of dominance rather than deterrence.

1441098505825636359.text:
In fact, under the current plan, many Minuteman III
missiles will need to be life extended through the mid-to-late 2030s while they are gradually replaced by the GBSD. My amendment simply pauses GBSD development for one year while @POTUS prepares his Nuclear Posture Review (NPR).

1441098504215011335.text: THREAD: Today, the House is voting on my #NDAA amendment to pause the development of the Ground Based Strategic Deterrent (#GBSD) missile program. The Air Force has said the Minuteman III missile, which GBSD would replace, could be life extended instead of being replaced.

1440783519161061377.text: I just spoke on the House floor about my amendment to the National Defense Authorization Act (NDAA) that would pause the development of the Ground Based Strategic Deterrent (GBSD) program. You can watch my remarks below: https://t.co/Vm8d6DxOhg

1434996871777423360.text: Unionized workers earn 11% more than their counterparts without union representation. Union workers also have better health benefits and access to paid sick leave on average. It's time to allow more workers to have a say in their workplace and pass the PRO Act.

1434996794581262336.text: Other provisions of the PRO Act would put an end to the gig economy exploitation of the independent contractor loophole. This loophole allows Lyft and Uber to pay fewer taxes, prevent their workers from unionizing and dodge labor protections.

1434996751140806657.text: Currently, when corporations like Amazon are found in violation of labor law they face no punishment. The PRO Act would allow the NLRB to fine these corporations, levying increasingly heavy fines for repeat offenders, ending illegal union-busting and protecting workers’ rights.

1434996651698135043.text: The PRO Act is the boldest piece of pro-worker legislation in 80 years. On Labor Day it is important to support workers and discuss this vital legislation. I am a cosponsor of the PRO Act which will empower workers and protect their right to organize.

1427695793134346249.text: President Biden has made the right decision to end a war that should have concluded years ago and not pass this conflict along to a fifth president. I appreciate his leadership and am firm in my commitment to help every U.S. citizen and Afghan ally return to safety today.

1427695671583420422.text: I've served on the House Armed Services Committee for 11 years. I have received countless briefings on the situation in Afghanistan, led delegations to the region, and studied the conflict and history at length.

1427695566524493831.text: Evacuation flights are moving steadily, and the work is being done to bring people to safety. My staff and I are also encouraging any constituent who has family in the region that needs to be brought to safety to contact my office at CA03.casework@mail.house.gov.

1427695530021429248.text: Today, our focus is on evacuating U.S. citizens and Afghan allies from the region safely and as quickly as possible. President Biden is sending additional troops to facilitate the departure of Americans and allied civilian personnel to safety.

1427695450103205890.text: We owe them a debt of gratitude and must recognize the work they’ve done to abate the threat of terrorism to our homeland. We must always honor their service and sacrifice.

1427695393182265351.text: This situation is difficult for American veterans and everyone who has spent the last 20 yrs in Afghanistan. Those who risked their lives and paid the ultimate cost for their service did so with dignity and honor while carrying out the policies and missions of four presidents.

1427695146288693252.text: The Afghanistan government wasn’t overthrown—it simply disappeared. President Biden was clear that we would not stay and force American soldiers to nation-build and fight indefinitely.

1427695076256399366.text: While the events that transpired over the last 3 days happened more precipitously than expected, they have confirmed that the decision to drawdown was the right one. Afghanistan’s political leadership fled the country, and its military collapsed without even attempting to fight.

1427694869066170374.text:
The latter would put thousands of additional American troops in harm’s way and thrust our nation into the third decade of conflict in Afghanistan. 

The President made the right decision.

1427694742373113862.text: Those who were silent while the previous administration pursued a full withdrawal and are now castigating the current administration are coated in hypocrisy. President Biden was faced with the choice of following through on that agreement or redoubling our efforts to fight

1427694641432956936.text: If he had not made this decision, there would be no ceasefire. No agreement protecting our forces. No status quo of stability without casualties.

1427694514249076736.text: When President Biden took office, there was a ceasefire agreement in place negotiated by President Trump and the Taliban. President Trump agreed to a full withdrawal of U.S. forces by May 1. President Biden extended this deadline until September.

1427694379037306886.text: THREAD: President Biden has a consummate understanding of the history of Afghanistan. He considered every fact and contingency and made the correct decision to drawdown the U.S. presence in the region. He was not willing to pass this war on to a fifth president.

It is my duty, your duty, and the duty of all Americans to understand the tragic consequences when we allow this type of hatred to continue.

1252681993244020738.text: As Co-Chair of the Congressional Peace Corps Caucus and as a returned Peace Corps volunteer, I understand how capable America’s service organizations are to expand our nation’s testing and contact tracing to meet the needs of our country’s pandemic response.

1252681992505888768.text: The coronavirus pandemic has put an unprecedented strain on our society, and our nation requires a significant scaling of testing and contact tracing in order to flatten the curve and lift stay-at-home orders.

1252681991654383623.text: The bill would also ensure that .@PeaceCorps volunteers, whose service involuntarily ended in March due to the global pandemic, will receive benefits & priority placement in these domestic programs so they can continue to use their skills by facilitating testing & contact tracing

1252681990782038016.text: The bicameral legislation ensures that existing national and community service programs are fully mobilized in order to assist in testing and contact tracing, especially for vulnerable Americans such as the food-insecure, elderly, and homeless.

1252681990018662402.text: The Undertaking National Initiatives to Tackle Epidemic Act (UNITE Act) would expand volunteer opportunities within .@AmeriCorps & .@fema and direct those agencies to enhance testing and contract tracing to identify and monitor the contacts of infected individuals.

1252681989255245824.text: Today I introduced legislation that would mobilize America’s service organizations to significantly expand testing and contact tracing for the coronavirus pandemic.

1237824578619088898.text: Military dogs serve on the front lines with our troops to defend our nation and provide recuperating services for our veterans and their former handlers. Caring for these dogs in the field and once they return home is a major concern that must be addressed.

1139167464019939333.text: I think the amended text made the bill even stronger. It’s now up to us as members of the Armed Services Committee to educate our fellow Reps on this bill and why, in my opinion, it deserves strong bipartisan support when the full House votes on it. #FY20NDAA.

1139167462400962560.text: And in case you were wondering, I voted for the bill. It passed by a bipartisan vote of 33-24 in committee. 1139149104905371648.text: After 21 hours of work, the #FY20NDAA has passed the Armed Services Committee. It’s been a pleasure walking through this process with you. Please feel free to comment with any questions you may have. Next, the bill will be voted on by the full House of Representatives.

1138908970440101888.text: The President called for a $750 billion top-line even after 23 of 26 Republicans on the Armed Services Committee sent him a letter supporting the $733 billion funding level. Why did he do this? #FY20NDAA.

1138908969580322818.text: Now we are expecting it to be a contentious issue during the markup. So what changed? Once again, the President threw a wrench into an issue with bipartisan support. The President did that here by asking for a higher top-line funding level. #FY20NDAA.

1138906357082546178.text: It's the sum of every authorization we fund in the entire bill. Right now the top-line funding level is $733 billion--which is exactly what the DOD planned and asked for. 1138827023361728513.text: We have included all other amendments with broad bipartisan support into the Intelligence and Emerging Threats and Capabilities Subcommittee mark through the en bloc process. We've voice voted the mark and are moving on to the next subcommittee's mark.

1138825518437085186.text: In this instance it was because the amendment required a waiver from another committee to be considered, but the other committee did not grant the waiver.

1138825517728223232.text: This amendment was withdrawn due to what's called a point of order. Points of order are prohibitions against certain types of legislation or congressional actions. These prohibitions are enforced when a Rep raises a point of order against legislation that may violate these rules

1138825516939714561.text: Now, as we work through the Intelligence and Emerging Threats and Capabilities Subcommittee markup, we have our first individual amendment that we will consider. When individual amendments like this are proposed the full committee debates it and oftentimes votes on it.

1138822230148866048.text: Voice voting is the quickest way to vote on something because we don't have to tally each Rep's vote. It's typically used when there's broad consensus on a vote or issue. It is the right of any Rep to request a recorded vote even if a voice vote is proposed.

1138822229414858753.text: En bloc is when we bundle noncontroversial amendments together and vote on them all at once. The Chair of the subcommittee provides an overview of the en bloc package before we vote on it.

1138822228659834882.text: The language for the TAL has been amended and adopted. It was a very quick process for this subcommittee's mark because it had broad bipartisan support and noncontroversial amendments. Because of that, the committee adopted the amendments en bloc and voice voted the mark.

1138818869680857088.text: Now we are reviewing and amending the subcommittee markup for the Intelligence and Emerging Threats and Capabilities Subcommittee. Here's an overview of the subcommittee and its jurisdictions: https://t.co/KLAumW38Rm

1138817018625495041.text: ^this sounds complicated, but think of it as individual chapters within a full book. We are reviewing and editing the TAL Subcommittee's chapter (their markup) to the full book (the NDAA). Members will try to edit the chapter before it's in the full book by introducing amendments

1138814581890068483.text: Here is the full text of the TAL's markup for the billthat we are discussing, amending, and then formally adopting into the NDAA (one of the things you learn quickly as a member of this committee is that you have to memorize a ton of acronyms): https://t.co/x6g8bTx5Sa

1105897104931737607.text: Climate change presents a myriad of readiness challenges both at home and abroad. It is not only a future threat but is impacting resiliency of our installations and operations today. The Department must act now to address these challenges.

1105896997708578817.text: Not only are these climate-related events impacting installation readiness, but they are also creating more frequent requests for military support for disaster relief and humanitarian assistance.

1105896842221494272.text: "...They will likely lead to food and water shortages, pandemic, disease, disputes over refugees and resources, and destruction by natural disasters in regions across the globe.”

1105896841521057794.text: “Rising global temperatures, changing precipitation patterns, climbing sea levels, and more extreme weather events will intensify the challenges of global instability, hunger, poverty, and conflict...

1105896840841646080.text: To ensure it can perform its national defense mandate, the Department of Defense must plan for a variety of exigencies. In the 2014 Climate Change Adaptation Roadmap, the Department noted that...

1105896840153743362.text:
Unfortunately, the report did not meet the congressional reporting
requirement to describe future focused mitigations necessary to ensure mission resiliency.

1105896838694141952.text: The required report was delivered to Congress in January 2019 and indicated that two thirds of the 79 installations reviewed are vulnerable to flooding, more than half are vulnerable to drought, and about half are vulnerable to wildfires.

1105896837200908288.text: It's essential that our bases and facilities recover quickly from extreme weather events and energy disruptions that impact mission capabilities. The FY18 National Defense Authorization Act required the Department of Defense to report on the Effects of Climate Change.

1105895186595569665.text: In many cases, through contract vehicles such as energy savings performance contracts, these energy saving and resiliency enhancing improvements can be made at no up-front cost to the Department.

1105895091825184768.text: One way to enhance readiness is to consume less. In FY 2017, the DOD consumed over 85 million barrels of fuel to power ships, aircraft, combat vehicles, and contingency bases at a cost of nearly $8.2 billion.

1105894716237930502.text: and the Department is uniquely situated to enhance its readiness and resiliency through effective energy policy and programs.

1105894714195218434.text: The U.S. military is one of the largest employers in the world. It is also one of its largest consumers of energy. The DOD owns millions of acres of global real property, including over 550,000 facilities valued over a trillion dollars...

1105894452772724736.text: Melting polar ice in Arctic regions has already opened new sea routes and competition for resources, yet it appears that DOD has not developed a systematic strategy for ensuring U.S. national interests in the Arctic.

1105894260736442371.text: California wildfires led to the evacuation of family housing at Camp Pendleton, Naval Air Station Point Mugu, and the Marine Corps Mountain Warfare Training Center. Our coastal installations are already experiencing significant flooding due to sea-level rise.

1105894052808015873.text: Is the US military ready for Climate Change? Recent events indicate considerable doubt. Just this last year Hurricanes Florence and Michael caused billions of dollars in damage to Camp Lejeune and leveled much of Tyndall Air Force Base.
